content.title: Thrombectomy (Surgical and Mechanical)
content.definition: Removal of thrombus from a blood vessel to restore flow, performed either surgically (open thrombectomy) using balloon catheters or endovascularly using mechanical thrombectomy devices. Essential treatment for acute limb ischemia and acute DVT.

key_concepts.description: Open arteriotomy with passage of balloon-tipped catheter (Fogarty catheter) beyond thrombus, inflation, and withdrawal to extract clot. Gold standard for acute arterial occlusion
Access through arteriotomy (usually common femoral); advance deflated catheter beyond clot; inflate balloon; withdraw with gentle traction; repeat until no further clot retrieved
Endovascular devices that fragment and aspirate thrombus: aspiration (AngioVac, Penumbra), rheolytic (AngioJet), rotational (Cleaner). For arterial and venous thrombosis
Large-bore catheter with suction to remove thrombus en bloc; Penumbra system common; less trauma than rheolytic; used for DVT, PE, arterial occlusion
AngioJet: high-velocity saline jets create Venturi effect to fragment and aspirate thrombus; effective but can cause hemolysis, bradycardia (adenosine release), renal injury
Combination of catheter-directed thrombolysis with mechanical thrombectomy; reduces lytic dose and treatment time; EKOS uses ultrasound to enhance lysis
Class IIa-IIb (viable but threatened) limb is ideal for revascularization; Class I may benefit from anticoagulation alone; Class III (irreversible) may require amputation
Open venous thrombectomy rarely performed now; endovascular pharmacomechanical preferred for iliofemoral DVT; goal is to reduce post-thrombotic syndrome
Angiography post-thrombectomy to assess residual thrombus and identify underlying lesion (stenosis, aneurysm) that may have caused thrombosis
Anticoagulation (heparin then warfarin/DOAC); fasciotomy if reperfusion injury/compartment syndrome; address underlying cause (embolism source, atherosclerosis)

learning_objectives: Know mechanical thrombectomy device types and indications
Recognize Rutherford classification for ALI decision-making
Understand importance of identifying underlying cause
clinical_pearls: Fogarty catheter = classic for acute arterial occlusion
Inflate balloon GENTLY - overinflation causes vessel injury
AngioJet can cause bradycardia (adenosine release) and hemolysis
Always look for underlying lesion after thrombectomy (why did it clot?)
Pharmacomechanical reduces lytic dose and time
Watch for compartment syndrome after reperfusion - low threshold for fasciotomy
common_mistakes: Overinflating Fogarty balloon (intimal injury, vessel rupture)
Using rheolytic thrombectomy without anticipating hemolysis
